Everyone enjoys that remark.  A gorgeous woman named LAUR moves closer to Peter, flirting.
I saw you on the news.  But I think you're even better live.
(interrupting) He is.  By the way, Lauren, did you ever finish your book on tattoo art?  I hear your publisher wants his advance back.
(cold) That's not true.
I think Rhonda Huston's assistant was just made an editor at S&S.
The guy with the weird fingernails?  Imagine looking over galleys with him.
So, Peter, how crowded is the field now?  There are, what, seven books in the offing about the Viznick case?
Yeah, but no one has the access I've got.
Is it true the cops used a psychic?
I saw a psychic once.  Some of these guys are definitely for real.
Oh, really?  I dropped $250 on a session once and they guy didn't get a thing right.
And you, Peter?  Where do you stand?
Wherever there's room.
Peter feels a tap on his shoulder.  A WAITER serving hors d'oeuvres is standing there.
None for me, thanks.
The waiter wipes the frame and as he does, John Townsend revealed, beads of sweat glistening on his brow and a gun his hand.
(whispering) God will forgive me, the time of transformation is so near.

He points it at Peter's face.  Peter is in shock.  Everyt around him seems to blur, except the gun floating a few f away.  But Townsend hesitates, obviously conflicted. And suddenly, the woman to Peter's left SCREAMS.  The waiter's tray goes flying.  With astonishing speed, Willi flings himself onto Townsend.  They both go down.  A SHOT RINGS OUT.  Pandemonium.  Screams & shouting.  Peter sees that William has Townsend in a brutal headlock.  Townsend looks panicked, helpless.  Peter is pulled back, as the t men disappear beneath a swarm of other bodies.

The enormous room is empty.  All the guests are gone.  Th uneaten food and overturned chairs testimony to their has departure.  Peter, Claire, Susan and William are sitting semi-circle.  Smythe walks over.
Thanks for handling this.

Sure thing.  Look, I've got enough, between your preliminary statements and all the witness accounts.  You can go home. (to Peter) Gimme til morning.  Find out who he is.  Until then, don't sweat it, huh?  Just your random bad cheese trying to hole you.
Well said.
Colloquialisms 101.  My only "A" in the Academy.
Peter stands and pats Smythe on the back.
Thanks again for everything.
Hey, don't thank me.  Somebody up there likes you.
Peter looks at William, then hugs him in a powerful embra
(moved) Will, this is...
It's okay.
They smile, exhausted.
Can we please leave now?
Peter and Claire exit a limo.  The scaffolding is still i place but the workers are gone.  Josef pushes open the do for Peter and Claire.
Good evening, Mr. Kelson.  Miss Claire.
Peter and Claire enter the lobby.
(urgent) I want to tell you...your neighbor, Mrs. Levotsky, she's dead.
Peter and Claire are both caught off guard.
What?  That's horrible!
What happened?

(enjoyably ghoulish) Apparently she killed herself sometime last night. (confidentially) The paramedics told me she hung herself.  Climbed up on her dresser, stocking around her neck, but I don't know.  She was completely rheumatoid... (realizes he's speaking with too much relish) It's a shame.  Anyway, though you should know.
Peter's stunned and now completely unnerved.
Yeah, I appreciate it.  Thanks, Josef.
(frightened) When did they find her?
A few hours ago.
Claire's blown away by the night's events.
Peter has slowed to look at the yellow police cordon, as Claire moves on into their apartment.
A bit later, Peter and Claire, both still shaken, sit acr from a relieved Father James, drinking coffee.
It's moments like this that make it clear.  All that matters is those we love are with us.
Peter's touched.  He pats James on the shoulder.
I'm still shaking.
I can't believe Will killed him.
Thank God he did.
Claire stands, exhausted.  She bends down, kissing Peter the cheek, only because James is there, and then she give Peter a sweet hug.
(deeply felt) I don't know what I'd do without you.
Peter hugs her tightly.  An emotional moment.
I'm going to bed.  Don't be long.
Claire exits.  James looks at Peter, sees the night's eve have taken their toll.
What is it?
Something he said, just before...
He spoke to you?
Yeah.  It didn't make any sense.
Listen to me, Peter.  You can't let the ravings of a madman disturb you, okay?
You're right, but it's funny.  All my life I thought I was simply a man who didn't believe in any of it.
No matter, my son, he believes in you.

But it's true.  I have no faith.  It's strange.  When that gun was pointed at my face tonight, I was surprised, but never frightened.  It was as if I knew nothing could possibly happen to me and...in that one moment I didn't care about anything.  Not eve my own life.
Peter.  Your life must matter to you because it matters to all of us who love you.
You know, I respect that you have such faith, James.  I don't understand it, but I want you to know that despite our differences, I admire you and I always will.
Father James stands and claps his hand on Peter's shoulde
I appreciate your saying that.  I'm gonna go now.  I believe you're wanted elsewhere.
Maya is making coffee in a drip pot on a hot plate.  Ther a soft knock on the door.
Come in.
Father Jeremy enters and shuts the door behind him.
His faith wavered.  He tried to shoot Kelson last night.  I don't know all the details.
Was anyone else hurt?
I don't know.  I don't think so.
A curious conflict of emotions passes across Maya's face sadness coupled with relief.  She sits heavily on the bed
Be careful, Maya.

The hustle and bustle of a typical weekday morning.  As P crosses the street, nearing his office, suddenly a MESSEN on a bicycle skids and falls.  The Messenger's on the gro crashed, his mail everywhere.  Immediately Peter moves to help him up, grabbing an arm, trying to collect the spill envelopes.  All the morning PEDESTRIANS step over or arou the mess, in typical New York fashion.  The embarrassed Messenger thanks Peter, AD-LIB, and we...

Peter's typing at his computer.  He is surrounded by newspaper clippings, interview transcripts and other rese relevant to the Viznick trial.  His printer JAMS.  As he moves to fix it, the intercom blinks.
Yeah.
It's Detective Smythe.
Peter picks up.
What's up?
How're you doin' today?
(tough) It's another day.  I think I'm alright.
You got the right attitude, anyway, look, we gotta talk.
Smythe exits the building just as Peter approaches.
I'm fed up inside, let's walk.
Peter and Smythe take a walk down the street.  Smythe sto moment at an outdoor vendor.  Buys a hotdog.

We traced this guy to a seminary in Newark.  If you can believe it, he was a deacon. (shifting a file under his arm) Talked to the man in charge there, a Father Frank Page.  He said the gunman, John Townsend, was caught up in some nonsense about the Devil, along with a priest named Lareaux and a woman named Maya Larkin - the same woman whose prints were on that coffee cup.  Now can I please get the fill?
Smythe licks a mouthful of mustard just ready to drip, th takes a huge bite off his dog.
She came to me with a wild story about demonic possession.
(hands Peter Maya's file) She's got a juvenile record from New Orleans.  Parents died when she was 13.
Parents died?
Yeah, murder-suicide.
What happened?
Mother killed the father, then killed herself.  Crime of passion.
She told me she killed them.

Not what the records show.  Anyway, she was a runaway, arrests for vandalism, petty theft, drugs, the whole bit.  Parole records show she graduated from community college, moved into a retreat house, teaches some classes at the seminary school, hasn't been in any trouble since.
Smythe finishes his hot dog and chucks the wrapper into a nearby can.

We hauled her in earlier but didn't have anything hard to tie her to Townsend.  Far as the priest goes, he won't be bothering you.  Suffered a complete mental breakdown, during - get this - during an exorcism.
Where is she now?
Had to let her go. (beat) I see you thinkin' there, superstar.  Don't.
Peter drives into the Lincoln Tunnel.  Two men stand outs the entrance, arguing.  As Peter passes, they begin fight
I'm sure I don't have to remind you she's still a possible accessory to attempted murder...
Maya stands before a roomful of children.  She holds an o sized picture of a hat.
Le Chapeau.
Tres bien.
...and the obvious, you could get another gun in your face.
Next is a picture of a dog.
Le Chien.
Don't worry, I won't go anywhere near her.
The door to the hall is abruptly flung open.  Peter strid in.  Maya sees his anger.
(harsh) We need to talk.
Peter, please...
Peter's overt belligerence scares the children.
Now!
He motions towards the door.  Maya turns to the class.
Children, I'll be right back.  Just stay in...
Peter grabs her and escorts her to the door.
(unconvincing smile) ...your seats.  Be right back.  Don't worry.
And as she's pulled into the hall, we SEE:

Maya, still holding the brightly colored vocabulary pictu stands with Peter in the hallway.  Opposite her in the ha is a window, and to the left, an old radiator with chippe enamel paint.  Next to the wall is a plain wooden bench.  Maya stands with her back to her classroom door.  She continually checks on her kids through a window in the do
(really pissed off) Last night a guy named John Townsend tried to shoot me and now I find out you knew him.  What the fuck is going on?
Please, the children.
Peter moves in close, crowding her against the wall.
(lowering his voice) Why did he try to kill me?
(looking at classroom) Townsend believed, just as God became man in Christ. (Maya turns back to Peter) So Satan will assume human form.  I believe it too.
Peter grabs the pictures out of her hand and pitches them into the hall.
And the point is?
At the exorcism, Birdson boasted that Satan is about to take over the body of a man. (long pause) You are that man, Peter.
What?!?!
It's true.  Birdson knew your name, he was writing it in numerical code.  It wasn't easy but I figured it out.  It spelled your name.
(sarcastic) Why didn't Birdson just say so?
If you're possessed, you can't reveal anything Satan wants hidden.  Unless you trick him.
(now completely unimpressed) Trick him.
The good outwitting the bad.  It's like Birdson had a split personality.
(he's had it; laughs) You should think about getting professional help.
You're already contaminated.  It's why you couldn't hear the tape.  There's probably a pentacle near your bed.  To sanctify you.
I'm not going to be drawn into this.
I know this sounds crazy.  I understand.  Check your parents' blood types.  Are you sure your parents are your birth parents?
My parents are dead.  Don't even think of bringing them into this.

The school bell rings.  Within seconds, the hallway is flooded with kids and teachers. A smiling Father Frank stops out of a classroom.  As he s Maya and Peter down the hall, his face darkens.  He start towards them.
(moving to Peter; whisper) You're about to become the anti-Christ who is born unholy and becomes the door to eternal suffering in this world.
(pissed off at himself now) If you or any of your lunatic friends ever come near me again...
Peter notices Father Frank moving up on Maya and takes of  EXT. STREET - OUTSIDE SEMINARY - DAY

An angry Peter walks to his Range Rover.  The wind is up it has started to rain.  Peter's under-dressed, hunching shoulders against the elements.  He's parked a distance f the Seminary.  As he begins a slow jog to his car, the ra begins to come down a bit harder.  Suddenly, Peter slips the wet pavement and falls, scraping his hand.  A moment, while he gets his bearings and then he picks himself up, rain now shooting down the side of his face.
An anxious Maya sits at her desk.  Suddenly, there's a ha knock on the door and Father Frank enters.  Maya looks up unprepared.

I've had it.  Townsend's dead.  The police are calling and now I see you having a scene in front of the children.  I'm sorry, Maya, you've been with us for many years, but effective immediately, I'm rescinding your right to live at the church.
Father, I have nowhere else to stay.
You have a sister in New Orleans.
Maya looks up at him, but Father Frank's out the door.

Father Lareaux sleeps quietly, quasi fetal.  Maya moves t the room soundlessly.  A renewed sadness stabs her at the sight of Lareaux.  She studies him a moment, then cups hi face in her hands.  Slight disturbance in Lareaux's body, like a child's startle reaction.  Maya lets go and leaves quietly as she came.
Upscale.  Claire and Peter at lunch.  Peter is clearly agitated.  His clothes are still wet and pretty wrinkled. Claire looks at him with tenderness.
I'm gonna have to get a restraining order.  What a nightmare.
I don't know.  In a way, I'm glad it all happened.
Peter looks at her skeptically, a little pissed off.
You're glad somebody tried to kill me?
(nervous about confronting him) No, of course not, but I think now that this has happened, a lot of things can start to come out...
(still pissed) Yeah, like...
(coming on a little stronger) Like you need to admit that losing your parents when you were twelve was traumatic.
(unafraid) It's with me all the time, Claire, I just don't like to talk about it.
Well, it shattered your faith in everything.
(trying to lighten it) I'm just temporarily off my game.
(boring in) You need to believe in something besides yourself.
I believe in you.
A moment where Claire hesitates, then she decides to let herself be flattered.
(leaning in, close to Peter) I love you.  You look a mess.  Why don't you go home and clean up before you go back to work.
Claire kisses Peter, brief but deep, as she gulps in a sh gust of air. Outside the rain has stopped as Claire gets up, taking of for work without him.
Maya is sitting on an iron bench outside the playground. shoulder bag with some of her belongings lays beside her. She stands, picks up her sack and walks across the street a small diner.

It's warm, crowded and NOISY.  WAITRESSES banter with longtime customers about the ups and downs of everyday li Maya enters in a state of complete distress.  She sits at counter next to a MOTHER and her LITTLE GIRL.  Their drin and sandwiches are spread out everywhere.  The little gir cusp her hand around a tall glass of milk.  She wears bla patent shoes, a red jacket, hood attached.  Maya bows her head and covers her eyes.  She's losing it...
(whisper) I can't do this anymore.
The little girl, about 4 years old, tugs on Maya's sleeve
You have to put your napkin in your lap.
(embarrassed) Gina!
Maya looks at the solemn little girl.
(to her mother) It's okay. (she puts her napkin in her lap) Better?
I'm sorry, she's very into rules.
Doesn't your daughter put her napkin in her lap?
(softly) I don't have a daughter.  I'm not married.
Aren't you lonely?
Okay, Gina, that's enough.
Maya sees the little girl wants an answer.  Moved, she be close and whispers in her ear.
I have someone who takes care of me.
She pulls back.  The little girl looks up at Maya reprovingly.
(cruelly) But he's dead.  Jesus is dead.

And then she smiles at Maya, a wicked smile.  Maya looks the little girl, and then at her mother.  The mother's ey are sparkling with malice.  The room begins to warp and distort.  And we hear a choked back breath. Horrified, Maya quickly turns in her chair and faces away from the vision, praying silently with eyes closed.  Afte moment, she opens her eyes.  The room looks normal again. the reflection of the mirror across the counter she sees the two seats next to her are empty, the utensils untouch Sighing with relief, she turns back.  But the little girl her mother are still there.  The mother's face suddenly l elongated, her eyes move too close together and her nose disappears.  A frightening distortion, but momentary.  An the little girl's smile widens with spite.
You're so weak.

With a loud, frightened cry, Maya sweeps her arms out, knocking all the nearby glasses, utensils and dishes to t floor with a tremendous crash.  Milk bleeds over the coun All eyes turn to her.  Distraught, Maya sees the little g and the mother are gone.  She grabs her bag and runs out diner.
It's quiet, shadowy.  The aquarium has begun a slow leak a small puddle of water has pooled beneath it.  Peter ent He notices the water on the floor.  He goes into the bedr

The ledge of the building across the way can be seen from Peter's window.  A WOMAN is moving near the ledge, settin out a grouping of potted geraniums.  From downstairs, a s of light is visible. Peter changes his clothes  Then, he feels the scrape on h hand.  Looks at it.  As he moves to the bathroom.  Washes hand and as he does so, he checks his reflection in the mirror.  Stares at himself a moment, then sticks out his tongue.  Checks it.  And then dries his hand, moving back the bedroom, carrying his towel with him.  Peter glances his bed a moment.  Half-amused, he leans over and checks behind the picture hanging above the headboard. Nothing. Then, he bends down, checking under the bed.  Again, noth Then, he moves to a bedroom closet, pulling down a black gray speckled file box. Inside, a series of newspaper clippings, graphic photos.  Yellowed with age, on of which falls on the bed, titled, "Unsolved Brutal Murders."  Peter riffles past the clippi to the coroner's report. He speed reads it, until he gets to his parents' blood ty "Andrea Kelson - A negative."  Jack Kelson - O positive." Peter stares at the information.  Confused by what it's supposed to mean.  Then, he pulls on a turtleneck sweater ready to go back out.
This is ridiculous.
Peter exits the bedroom and steps back towards the living room, carrying the towel.
Peter passes through to his front door throwing his towel the puddle of water.
Peter walks in, eyeballing Mrs. Quintana's desk.
Good of you to stop by.
(breezy) We millionaires yet?
Peter enters to find Michael.  Peter sizes up the man who casually studying Peter's personal desk photos.
Umm, Melvin Szabo, this is Peter Kelson.  Peter, this is the psychic.
The stranger looks up.  He's young and cocky, with thick glasses.  He's holding a picture of Peter with his parent
(to Melvin) I'd appreciate it if you'd put that back.
You are the younger of two...
He puts down that photo and picks up one of Claire, as Pe walks over to his chair and a position of more control.
(indicating Claire) You're afraid of committing to this girl.
Peter grabs one of his pens and begins rolling it between fingers.
But she worships you.  Your mother's dead but your father's alive.
Nothing you couldn't find out from reading the papers.  And you're already wrong on one count.
Viznick will get off and Michael's got a crush on you.
Michael looks alarmed.  Peter notices his pen is leaking over his hand.
You know what?  You can go.
Suit yourself.  But does this mean anything to you?
Melvin picks up a pen and writes "X-E-S" in florid script a pad.  He holds it out for Peter's inspection.  Peter is rattled.
You do know, don't you.  That these are also numbers.  Greek numbers, 600, 60 and 6 - or 666.  The sign of the Devil.
Get out of here.
(pleasantly) Goodbye.
He sticks out his hand and grabs Peter's.  His expression changes from one of amused disdain to fascinated curiosit
Wait a minute...
His arrogance melts away.  Melvin's face tightens.  A shu of fear passes through him.
(strangled gasp) God will forgive me...the time of transformation is so near.
But the voice is that of John Townsend.
(really shaken) Get the fuck out of here!
Peter stands in the middle of the sidewalk as the wind violently whips at his jacket.  He gazes upward to the mu gray sky.  Finally he lowers his eyes.  He sees something that angers him.

A sprawling Catholic church stands before him.  Peter reg it with wrath.  He pushes open the door and tries to ente but a group of LITHUANIAN parishioners pushes past him, blocking his way. A priest calls a farewell.
(in Lithuanian) See you all next week!
The entry finally clear, Peter goes inside.
It's dark, forbidding.  The priest exits around a corner. Peter looks at the vast and spacious altar.  Above it is enormous wooden crucifix.  Peter moves down the aisle tow the altar.

The sorrowful face of the Christ figure looks down on Pet with pity.  The body hangs, gaunt, wracked with pain.  Th wrists pierced by nails, the feet cruelly hammered togeth Peter stops at the first pew.  He looks up at the crucifi Defiant.
Go ahead, do something.  Show me.

He waits.  For a split-second, there's a pristine silence Then the sound of the wind rises in the church.  With tha the right wrist SHATTERS with a noise like a rifle shot.  Freed from one of its supports, the heavy wooden Christ S FORWARD at an awkward angle.  The other wrist SNAPS IN TW For a second, the Christ figure trembles.  Then, with a sickening sound, the entire wooden body falls forward, sw sideways and PLUMMETS down.  Peter doesn't want to look. figure is now hanging upside down, held only by the brace its feet.  Above it, each hand remains pinned to the cros It's an EXACT COPY of Viznick's tattoo.
Birdson's eyes open.

Peter staggers outside, dodging two DOGS fighting, a vici NOISY battle on the Rectory lawn.  And in the b.g., a homeless man takes a piss into a rivulet of white liquid. Peter walks in a daze, pulling his car keys from his pock
Peter's car moves through traffic, driving slowly, erratically.  He scrapes a parked car, but doesn't stop, Corners poorly, almost hitting a pedestrian.

Peter pulls up in his Range Rover across the street from playground.  He gets out of his car and crosses the stree As Peter walks closer, he sees Maya.  She's sitting on a swing, looking off into space, rocking ever-so-slightly b and forth, a pile of smoked, crushed cigarettes and her shoulder bag at her feet.

Standing beside Maya is an agitated DAY-CARE WORKER.  The conversation is FAINTLY AUDIBLE.  Across the yard, a SECO DAY-CARE WORKER is shepherding the last of the kids back inside the center.  The children are carefree and rambunctious, unaware of the adult drama taking place aro them.
Go on, get them inside! (sympathetically to Maya) Look, you don't have a job here anymore.  They want you to leave.

Maya's face.  She's devastated.  In the b.g., a YOUNG GIR does a triple on the roll bar.  Three girls and one boy compete for distance on the monkey bars. The Latino Boy and one of his friends LAUGH and break fre from the line heading back to the school.  They circle ba toward Maya and swoop by her, waving exuberantly, then re to the line and go into the school.  The day-care worker follows them as: Peter walks through the gate.  He walks fast toward Maya, sees him coming, from a distance.  Maya continues rocking ever so gently on her swing.  Peter puts out his hands an stops it.  Stares at her, scared.
(lost) I don't understand what's going on.

There's no reason why you should. (tells him as gently as possible) This has been planned from your birth.  You fit all the criteria that we know of.  Never baptized, born of incest, devoid of faith...
But I was baptized.  And I certainly wasn't born of incest.
You were not baptized.  At least I don't believe it was Christian.  Your baptism was performed by your uncle, James McKenzie.
Yes, I know.
The only baptism he ever performed in seven years as pastor at Bedford.
So what?
Seven years.  One baptism?  He's your mother's only brother
Yes.
Maya stares at Peter.
Do you know your parents' blood types?
I looked at the coroner's report.  My father's O positive and my mother...A negative.
(taking this in a gasp of air) Peter, your blood-type is AB negative.  There's no way your birth father can be O positive.  You father is not who you think he is.
(really shaken) So...then the coroner's report is probably wrong.  I mean...this is ridiculous.  There's been a mistake.  I don't believe any of this.
Then why are you here?
That silences Peter.  He sits heavily in the swing next t her.
Peter, I believe your baptism was perverted.  Look at your certificate.  Your mother was the only witness to it.  Your blood-type doesn't match who you thought your father was.  Peter...I'm sorry.
(desperate) And if what you're saying is true, what would happen to me?
I don't know. (beat) I do know that people who are possessed have to accept evil in some way.  I don't know if it works the same way in this instance.  I don't even know when it's going to happen.
Peter looks at Maya for solace, but there is none.  He glances away, runs a hand through his hair and...
When Townsend tried to kill me, he said something strange like... (struggles to remember) "The time of transformation is near..."
(putting something together) Townsend, he had some of Father's books.
As night falls, the Range Rover moves out of the suburbs deeper into the countryside.  There's a bright moon.  The highway is a ribbon of silver.

head_text.subj: EXT. RURAL ROAD- LATER THAT NIGHT

text: Their car pulls up to a dirt driveway.  Bordered by saggi fences, the mail box reads "Townsend."  At the end of the driveway is a two-story, weather-beaten farmhouse with a garage.  There are no lights on.  Maya says a silent pray and steels herself.

The ground floor windows are shuttered.  Maya tries the f door.  It's locked.  Peter walks to the end of the porch, looking for another entrance.  Maya looks at the door, th jams her elbow through a small pane of glass next to the doorknob, breaking it.
(inward smile at Maya) Okay.

Peter and Maya enter the dark hall.  Peter reaches for a light switch and flips it on.  They see a hallway in fron them, stairs to the right and living room off to the left For a moment, they stand in silence.  Peter opens a close door, glancing inside.
What are you looking for exactly?
The books themselves or maybe some pages he ripped out.
Maya walks into the living room.

The furniture is shabby and worn.  There's a battered sof new TV and a coffee table.  Maya goes to the table and quickly looks through a pile of magazines.  Peter enters makes a fast tour of the room.  Maya gestures towards the entrance of an adjacent room.
In here.

Maya turns on a standing lamp.  This room looks more promising.  There's an old piano in one corner.  On one w are two bookshelves.  And next to a set of wooden chairs small reading table.  Maya starts scanning the rows of bo Peter is immediately drawn to the table where he sees new copies of his books.  Chilled, Peter turns to Maya.
He's got all my books.
Maya looks over at Peter.
We needed to know all we could.
I'm going to look around.
Peter crosses the hallway into the dining room.

The room's dominated by a long wooden dining table, cover with a chintz tablecloth.  The window shutters are open a moonlight streams in. Peter tries the light switch.  It doesn't work.  He walks around the room - and is spooked by a glimpse of movement It's his own reflection in a mirror.  He sees a closet do and opens it.  Inside, it's totally dark.  He pulls a han cord.  A light goes on revealing a small pantry filled wi canned goods, foodstuff. Peter goes to the other side of the pantry and opens anot door.
Maya continues to comb through the bookshelves.

Peter steps into a dingy kitchen.  A dirty coffee cup and plate sit on the counter near the sink.  At the other end the kitchen, past the refrigerator, is a door leading outside.  Peter approaches the door, glances through the window.  He then turns and walks through a doorway.
Peter stands at the base of the rear staircase.  As he st to ascend the stairs.
(calling out) I'll be upstairs.
Maya is flipping through Peter's books.  Suddenly, she he the tread of footsteps overhead.  It startles her.
(reassuring herself) Peter...
She puts down the book and turns around.  Surveying the r she sees an entrance to the hallway that services the mas bedroom.
Maya walks through the hall towards the open door of the master bedroom.  She goes in.

An antique oak bed dominates the room, with two suitcases lying on top.  The place is a mess - clothes strewn everywhere.  There's a roll-top desk in the corner with s books and papers on it.  One of Townsend's jackets is dra on the desk chair. On the opposite wall is a door that's open just a crack. interior of a bathroom is visible on the other side.  The door has a smoky, opaque window built into its top half. Maya starts sifting through the papers on the desk.  She hear Peter's footsteps moving slowly above her.  And the sound of doors opening. She opens the desk drawers.  The first one is stuffed wit bills.  The second has checkbooks, bank statements.  The third is stuck shut. Maya kneels down to get better leverage.  From this perspective, we can see the open door to the dark hallway behind her...She pulls and pulls again.  As the drawer po open, a shadow falls across her.  She WHIRLS.
It's Peter.
Not much upstairs  A couple of empty bedrooms and a bathroom.  Anything here?
Maya looks at the contents of the drawer.  It's full of Christian literature.
Nothing yet.
I'll go outside and take a look in the garage.

Maya nods.  Peter exits the room.  She hears his footstep fade away and a door slam.  As she stands up, she knocks Townsend's jacket off the chair.  A book falls out of a pocket.  It's on of the books Townsend took from Lareaux' room.  Maya opens it.
Tiny, cryptic notations are scrawled in the margins.
Peter walks down the side steps and over to the large gar
